Select a home to add to your Tibber integration.

**Note:** After adding this home, you can add additional homes from the integration's context menu by selecting "Add Tibber Home".

init.title: General Settings

data.extended_descriptions: Show extended descriptions in entity attributes

current_interval_price_rating.title: Price Rating Thresholds
current_interval_price_rating.description:
{step_progress}

Configure thresholds for price rating levels (low/normal/high) based on comparison with trailing 24-hour average.

best_price.title: Best Price Period Settings
best_price.description:
{step_progress}

Configure settings for the Best Price Period binary sensor. This sensor is active during periods with the lowest electricity prices.

data.best_price_min_distance_from_avg: Minimum Distance: Required below daily average
data.enable_min_periods_best: Try to Achieve Minimum Period Count

data_description.best_price_max_level: Only show best price periods if they contain intervals with price levels ≤ selected value. For example, selecting 'Cheap' means the period must have at least one 'VERY_CHEAP' or 'CHEAP' interval. This ensures 'best price' periods are not just relatively cheap for the day, but actually cheap in absolute terms. Select 'Any' to show best prices regardless of their absolute price level.
data_description.best_price_max_level_gap_count: Maximum number of consecutive intervals allowed that deviate by exactly one level step from the required level. For example: with 'Cheap' filter and gap count 1, a sequence 'CHEAP, CHEAP, NORMAL, CHEAP' is accepted (NORMAL is one step above CHEAP). This prevents periods from being split by occasional level deviations. Default: 0 (strict filtering, no tolerance).
data_description.enable_min_periods_best: When enabled, filters will be gradually relaxed if not enough periods are found. This attempts to reach the desired minimum number of periods, which may include less optimal time windows as best-price periods.
data_description.min_periods_best: Minimum number of best price periods to aim for per day. Filters will be relaxed step-by-step to try achieving this count. Only active when 'Try to Achieve Minimum Period Count' is enabled. Default: 1
data_description.relaxation_step_best: Percentage of the original flexibility threshold to add per relaxation step. For example: with 15% flexibility and 25% step size, filters will try 15%, 18.75%, 22.5%, etc. Higher values mean faster relaxation but less precision.
data_description.relaxation_attempts_best: How many flex levels (attempts) to try before giving up. Each attempt runs all filter combinations at the new flex level. More attempts increase the chance of finding additional periods at the cost of longer processing time.

peak_price.title: Peak Price Period Settings
peak_price.description:
{step_progress}

Configure settings for the Peak Price Period binary sensor. This sensor is active during periods with the highest electricity prices.

data.peak_price_flex: Flexibility: Maximum below maximum price (negative value)
data.peak_price_min_distance_from_avg: Minimum Distance: Required above daily average
data.enable_min_periods_peak: Try to Achieve Minimum Period Count

data_description.peak_price_min_level: Only show peak price periods if they contain intervals with price levels ≥ selected value. For example, selecting 'Expensive' means the period must have at least one 'EXPENSIVE' or 'VERY_EXPENSIVE' interval. This ensures 'peak price' periods are not just relatively expensive for the day, but actually expensive in absolute terms. Select 'Any' to show peak prices regardless of their absolute price level.
data_description.peak_price_max_level_gap_count: Maximum number of consecutive intervals allowed that deviate by exactly one level step from the required level. For example: with 'Expensive' filter and gap count 2, a sequence 'EXPENSIVE, NORMAL, NORMAL, EXPENSIVE' is accepted (NORMAL is one step below EXPENSIVE). This prevents periods from being split by occasional level deviations. Default: 0 (strict filtering, no tolerance).
data_description.enable_min_periods_peak: When enabled, filters will be gradually relaxed if not enough periods are found. This attempts to reach the desired minimum number of periods to ensure you're warned about expensive periods even on days with unusual price patterns.
data_description.min_periods_peak: Minimum number of peak price periods to aim for per day. Filters will be relaxed step-by-step to try achieving this count. Only active when 'Try to Achieve Minimum Period Count' is enabled. Default: 1
data_description.relaxation_step_peak: Percentage of the original flexibility threshold to add per relaxation step. For example: with -15% flexibility and 25% step size, filters will try -15%, -18.75%, -22.5%, etc. Higher values mean faster relaxation but less precision.
data_description.relaxation_attempts_peak: How many flex levels (attempts) to try before giving up. Each attempt runs all filter combinations at the new flex level. More attempts increase the chance of finding additional peak periods at the cost of longer processing time.

price_trend.title: Price Trend Thresholds
price_trend.description:
{step_progress}

Configure thresholds for price trend sensors. These sensors compare the current price with the average of the next N hours to determine if prices are rising, falling, or stable.

data.price_trend_threshold_falling: Falling Threshold (below current price, negative value)

chart_data_export.title: Chart Data Export
chart_data_export.description:
{step_progress}

**⚠️ This step is optional** and only relevant if you plan to enable the **Chart Data Export** diagnostic sensor.

**⚠️ IMPORTANT: Legacy Feature**
This sensor exists for **backwards compatibility** with tools that can only read entity attributes (e.g., older ApexCharts versions). **For new integrations, use the `tibber_prices.get_chartdata` service directly** - it's more flexible, efficient, and the recommended Home Assistant approach.

**When to use this sensor:**
- ✅ Your dashboard tool can ONLY read attributes (not call services)
- ✅ You need static data that updates automatically
- ❌ NOT recommended for new integrations that support service calls

**What is this sensor?**
This sensor calls the `tibber_prices.get_chartdata` service with your custom YAML parameters and exposes the result as entity attributes.

**How to use it:**
1. **Complete this configuration** (or leave empty for service defaults)
2. Go to **Settings → Devices & Services → Tibber Prices**
3. Click on your home → Find **'Chart Data Export'** in the **Diagnostic** section
4. Enable the sensor - it will automatically call the service with your configuration
5. Use the sensor's attributes in your dashboard cards

**Configuration guide:**
1. Test your service call in **Developer Tools → Services → `tibber_prices.get_chartdata`**
2. Copy the YAML from the `data:` section (without `entry_id`)
3. Paste it below (use **Shift+Enter** or **Ctrl+Enter** for new lines, NOT just Enter)

**Example YAML:**
```yaml
day:
  - today
  - tomorrow
include_level: true
include_rating_level: true
```

**Note:** Leave empty to use service defaults or skip this feature if you don't need the sensor.

data_description.chart_data_config: YAML configuration for get_chartdata service. Supported parameters: day (list of yesterday/today/tomorrow), resolution (interval/hourly), output_format, include_level, include_rating_level, include_average, and many more. See service documentation for full list. Leave empty to use service defaults (today, interval resolution, array of objects).

volatility.title: Price Volatility Thresholds
volatility.description:
{step_progress}

Configure thresholds for volatility classification. Volatility measures relative price variation using the coefficient of variation (CV = standard deviation / mean × 100%). These thresholds are percentage values that work across all price levels.

Used by:
• Volatility sensors (classification)
• Trend sensors (adaptive threshold adjustment: <moderate = more sensitive, ≥high = less sensitive)

new_homes_available.title: New Tibber homes detected
new_homes_available.description: We detected {count} new home(s) on your Tibber account: {homes}. You can add them to Home Assistant through the Tibber integration configuration.

homes_removed.title: Tibber homes removed
homes_removed.description: We detected that {count} home(s) have been removed from your Tibber account: {homes}. Please review your Tibber integration configuration.

get_apexcharts_yaml.name: Get ApexCharts Card YAML
get_apexcharts_yaml.description: Returns a ready-to-copy YAML snippet for an ApexCharts card visualizing Tibber Prices for the selected day. Use this to easily add a pre-configured chart to your dashboard. The YAML will use the get_chartdata service for data.

entry_id.name: Entry ID
entry_id.description: The config entry ID for the Tibber integration.

day.name: Day
day.description: Which day to visualize (yesterday, today, or tomorrow).

level_type.name: Level Type
level_type.description: Select which price level classification to visualize: 'rating_level' (low/normal/high based on your configured thresholds) or 'level' (Tibber API levels: very cheap/cheap/normal/expensive/very expensive).

get_chartdata.name: Get Chart Data
get_chartdata.description: Returns price data in a simple chart-friendly format compatible with the Tibber Core integration output structure. Perfect for use with popular chart cards like ha-price-timeline-card, ApexCharts Card, Plotly Graph Card, Mini Graph Card, or the built-in History Graph Card. Field names and data structure can be customized to match your specific chart requirements.

entry_id.name: Entry ID
entry_id.description: The config entry ID for the Tibber integration.

day.name: Day
day.description: Which day(s) to fetch prices for. You can select multiple days. If not specified, returns all available data (today + tomorrow if available).

resolution.name: Resolution
resolution.description: Time resolution for the returned data. Options: 'interval' (default, 15-minute intervals, 96 points per day), 'hourly' (hourly averages, 24 points per day).

output_format.name: Output Format
output_format.description: Output format for the returned data. Options: 'array_of_objects' (default, array of objects with customizable field names), 'array_of_arrays' (array of [timestamp, price] arrays with trailing null point for stepline charts).

array_fields.name: Array Fields (Array of Arrays only)
array_fields.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Arrays FORMAT] Define which fields to include. Use field names in curly braces, separated by commas. Available fields: start_time, price_per_kwh, level, rating_level, average. Fields will be automatically enabled even if include_* options are not set. Leave empty for default (timestamp and price only).

minor_currency.name: Minor Currency
minor_currency.description: Return prices in minor currency units (cents for EUR, øre for NOK/SEK) instead of major currency units. Disabled by default.

round_decimals.name: Round Decimals
round_decimals.description: Number of decimal places to round prices to (0-10). If not specified, uses default precision (4 decimals for major currency, 2 for minor currency).

include_level.name: Include Level (Array of Objects only)
include_level.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Include the Tibber price level field (VERY_CHEAP, CHEAP, NORMAL, EXPENSIVE, VERY_EXPENSIVE) in each data point.

include_rating_level.name: Include Rating Level (Array of Objects only)
include_rating_level.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Include the calculated rating level field (LOW, NORMAL, HIGH) based on your configured thresholds in each data point.

include_average.name: Include Average (Array of Objects only)
include_average.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Include the daily average price in each data point for comparison.

level_filter.name: Level Filter
level_filter.description: Filter intervals to include only specific Tibber price levels (VERY_CHEAP, CHEAP, NORMAL, EXPENSIVE, VERY_EXPENSIVE). If not specified, all levels are included.

rating_level_filter.name: Rating Level Filter
rating_level_filter.description: Filter intervals to include only specific rating levels (LOW, NORMAL, HIGH). If not specified, all rating levels are included.

period_filter.name: Period Filter
period_filter.description: Filter intervals to include only those within Best Price or Peak Price periods. Options: 'best_price' (only intervals in Best Price periods), 'peak_price' (only intervals in Peak Price periods). If not specified, all intervals are included. This uses the precomputed period data from binary sensors.

insert_nulls.name: Insert NULL Values
insert_nulls.description: Control NULL value insertion for filtered data. 'none' (default): No NULL values, only matching intervals. 'segments': Add NULL points at segment boundaries for clean gaps in charts (recommended for stepline charts). 'all': Insert NULL for all timestamps where filter doesn't match (useful for continuous time series visualization).

add_trailing_null.name: Add Trailing Null Point
add_trailing_null.description: [BOTH FORMATS] Add a final data point with null values (except timestamp) at the end. Some chart libraries need this to prevent extrapolation/interpolation to the viewport edge when using stepline rendering. Leave disabled unless your chart requires it.

start_time_field.name: Start Time Field Name (Array of Objects only)
start_time_field.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Custom name for the start time field in the output. Defaults to 'start_time' if not specified.

end_time_field.name: End Time Field Name (Array of Objects only)
end_time_field.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Custom name for the end time field in the output. Defaults to 'end_time' if not specified. Only used with period_filter.

price_field.name: Price Field Name (Array of Objects only)
price_field.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Custom name for the price field in the output. Defaults to 'price_per_kwh' if not specified.

level_field.name: Level Field Name (Array of Objects only)
level_field.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Custom name for the level field in the output. Defaults to 'level' if not specified. Only used when include_level is enabled.

rating_level_field.name: Rating Level Field Name (Array of Objects only)
rating_level_field.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Custom name for the rating_level field in the output. Defaults to 'rating_level' if not specified. Only used when include_rating_level is enabled.

average_field.name: Average Field Name (Array of Objects only)
average_field.description: [ONLY FOR Array of Objects FORMAT] Custom name for the average field in the output. Defaults to 'average' if not specified. Only used when include_average is enabled.

data_key.name: Data Key (both formats)
data_key.description: [BOTH FORMATS] Custom name for the top-level data key in the response. Defaults to 'data' if not specified. For ApexCharts compatibility with Array of Arrays, use 'points'.

refresh_user_data.name: Refresh User Data
refresh_user_data.description: Forces a refresh of the user data (homes, profile information) from the Tibber API. This can be useful after making changes to your Tibber account or when troubleshooting connectivity issues.

entry_id.name: Entry ID
entry_id.description: The config entry ID for the Tibber integration.

options.level: Tibber Level (very cheap to very expensive)
